docs.title: Admin Panel API for plugins
docs.description: A Strapi plugin can interact with both the back end or the front end of the Strapi app. The Admin Panel API is about the front end part, i.e. it allows a plugin to customize Strapi's admin panel.

docs.title: Controllers
docs.description: Controllers are JavaScript files that contain a set of methods, called actions, reached by the client according to the requested route. Whenever a client requests the route, the action performs the business logic code and sends back the response. Controllers represent the C in the model-view-controller (MVC) pattern.

docs.title: Welcome to the Strapi Developer Docs!
docs.description: You're reading the bleeding edge version of our documentation. Some features might still be buggy.

docs.title: Configuring fields for content-types
docs.description: The Content-type Builder is only accessible to create and update content-types when your Strapi application is in a development environment, else it will be in a read-only mode in other environments.

docs.title: Creating content-types
docs.description: The Content-type Builder is only accessible to create and update content-types when your Strapi application is in a development environment, else it will be in a read-only mode in other environments.

docs.title: Introduction to the Content-type Builder
docs.description: The Content-type Builder is a core plugin of Strapi. It is a feature that is always activated by default and cannot be deactivated. The Content-type Builder is however only accessible when the application is in a development environment.

docs.title: Managing content-types
docs.description: The Content-type Builder is only accessible to create and update content-types when your Strapi application is in a development environment, else it will be in a read-only mode in other environments.

docs.title: Welcome to the Strapi User Guide!
docs.description: This user guide contains the functional documentation related to all features available in the admin panel of your Strapi application.

docs.title: Admin Panel API for plugins
docs.description: A Strapi plugin can interact with both the back end or the front end of the Strapi app. The Admin Panel API is about the front end part, i.e. it allows a plugin to customize Strapi's admin panel.

docs.title: Controllers
docs.description: Controllers are JavaScript files that contain a set of methods, called actions, reached by the client according to the requested route. Whenever a client requests the route, the action performs the business logic code and sends back the response. Controllers represent the C in the model-view-controller (MVC) pattern.

docs.title: Welcome to the Strapi Developer Docs!
docs.description: This documentation contains all technical documentation related to the setup, deployment, update and customization of your Strapi application.

docs.title: Configuring fields for content-types
docs.description: Content-types are composed of one or several fields. Each field is designed to contain specific kind of data, filled up in the Content Manager (see Writing content).

docs.title: Creating content-types
docs.description: The Content-type Builder allows to create new content-types: single and collection types. Although they are not proper content-types as they cannot exist independently, components can also be created through the Content-type Builder, in the same way as collection and single types.

docs.title: Introduction to the Content-type Builder
docs.description: The Content-type Builder is a core plugin of Strapi. It is a feature that is always activated by default and cannot be deactivated. The Content-type Builder is however only accessible when the application is in a development environment.

docs.title: Managing content-types
docs.description: The Content-type Builder allows to manage any existing content-type or component, even if it is already being used in the Content Manager. They can only be managed one at a time.

docs.title: Welcome to the Strapi User Guide!
docs.description: This user guide contains the functional documentation related to all features available in the admin panel of your Strapi application.

metadata.title: Greetings!
metadata.description: Congratulations, you have made your first post!

blogPosts.content:
Congratulations, you have made your first post!

Feel free to play around and edit this post as much you like.

metadata.title: Welcome
metadata.description: Docusaurus blogging features are powered by the blog plugin.

blogPosts.content:
[Docusaurus blogging features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/blog) are powered by the [blog plugin](https://docusaurus.io/docs/api/plugins/@docusaurus/plugin-content-blog).

Simply add Markdown files (or folders) to the `blog` directory.

Regular blog authors can be added to `authors.yml`.

The blog post date can be extracted from filenames, such as:

- `2019-05-30-welcome.md`
- `2019-05-30-welcome/index.md`

A blog post folder can be convenient to co-locate blog post images:

![Docusaurus Plushie](./docusaurus-plushie-banner.jpeg)

The blog supports tags as well!

**And if you don't want a blog**: just delete this directory, and use `blog: false` in your Docusaurus config.

metadata.title: MDX Blog Post
metadata.description: Blog posts support Docusaurus Markdown features, such as MDX.

blogPosts.content:
Blog posts support [Docusaurus Markdown features](https://docusaurus.io/docs/markdown-features), such as [MDX](https://mdxjs.com/).

:::tip

Use the power of React to create interactive blog posts.

```js
<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>
```

<button onClick={() => alert('button clicked!')}>Click me!</button>

:::

metadata.title: Long Blog Post
metadata.description: This is the summary of a very long blog post,

blogPosts.content:
This is the summary of a very long blog post,

Use a `<!--` `truncate` `-->` comment to limit blog post size in the list view.

<!--truncate-->

info.title: Strapi REST API
info.description: The REST API allows accessing the content-types through API endpoints. Strapi automatically creates API endpoints when a content-type is created. API parameters can be used when querying API endpoints to refine the results.

get.description: Return a post with postId equals to id.

200.description: A blog posts in JSON format

put.description: A  complete replacement of a post with id.

patch.description: Update the post with id partially.

get.description: Return comments on a post with postId={id}.

parameters.name: postId
parameters.description: The postId which we want the comments

200.description: A list of comments JSON format

example.title: First post
example.body: This is the first post body.

body.description: The body content of the post

example.title: The First Post
example.body: we are building a blog post API using OpenAPI Specification.

body.description: The body content of the post

example.name: id labore ex et quam laborum
example.body: laudantium enim quasi est quidem magnam voluptate

example.name: quo vero reiciendis velit similique earum
example.body: est natus enim nihil est dolore omnis voluptatem

email.description: The email of the user who posted the comment.
